reviewText:
Alright, alright. Seriously. This game is FREE.

If that, plus the extremely high ratings from the reviewers isn't enough to convince you to try it, I'll just add my review as well. I suck at reviews so I don't write them often, but some games just deserve my recognition.

To begin with, it is worth mentioning that this game was built with RPG Maker, such as multiple other games released on Steam (and which accidentally, are overpriced and atrocious in the majority).
Well, don't let that mislead you - Eternal Senia is in NO WAY even close to being considered a bad game.

Here are the reasons:

1. The combat system.
No, it's not using the usual boring turned-based combat system from RPG Maker. Yesss.
Instead, the developer designed his very own ARPG battle system, which means that the combat happens on-screen, directly on the map as you encounter enemies. No button mashing either. You just walk into an enemy to fight it.

But wait
date: doesn't that get very boring very quickly?"\n\nNope. The developer didn't forget to add diversity to the combat system either. Firstly
recommended: different enemies you encounter will have different combat skills. Secondly
hoursPlayed:
YOU will unlock skills as well. The combination of perfectly balanced skills and enemy difficulty makes this game's combat system extremely appealing and fluent.

2. The story.
Did any of you ever play a game which
voteText: although being fairly short
helpfulPercent: took you on a ride on a wave of emotions? Because this is an approximately accurate description of this game's story.\n\nI won't be lingering on talking about the story - after all
votesHelpful: I'm not here to spoil anything.\nAll I'll say for now is that the game has a total of 3 endings
votesTotal: all very slightly different. However
votesFunny: remain reassured that luckily
commentsCount: all three endings will not require you to replay the entire game; saving the game when prompted is recommended if you want to go back and get all the other endings (which I HIGHLY recommend
column16: by the way).\n\nThe only thing which may turn off a few of you grammar nazs is the fact that some words may be spelled incorrectly
column17: and some grammar mistakes can be found in the text. But give the developer a break here - this is translated
column18: you should be happy that you can have it in English language at all
column19: right? Besides
column21: in fact it barely even annoyed me
column23: you're still reading? You probably would have had the time to download the game already.\nSeriously though
column24: give it a try. Come on! It's free for fu... For the love of video games. What have you got to lose except a few minutes
column25:
which is what you've just wasted reading my longer-than-was-supposed-to-be review.

TL;DR: Definitely worth playing. And IT'S FU... It's FREE dammit.
What have you got to lose

reviewText:
There's a Legendary Sheep
There are Multiple Endings
The combat is amazing
Story made me cry
My family questioned the large amount of tissues in the trash
10/10 Would cry again.





















Oright, Now I'll be serious.

I've played through all endings, and to say the least, this game was the closest to making me cry out of all games I have ever played. There is a few grammar errors, but I would let that slide since the game was originally made in chinese. I have enjoyed both of my playthroughs of this, and you can probably 100% it in about 4 hours tops.

There is news of a sequal, though I've heard the developer is only planning on releasing it on Android, Which if he does, Will probably get me close to crying as well.

Oh, If anyone wanted to know, Difficulty does NOT affect the ending.

Overall, the game is fun and easy to play, But as a warning....


Don't fight the final boss on hard mode, The nuns will make you rage.
(It took me well over 100 trys to beat the Hard final Boss)

Oh and can we get some fan art of Senia in that white shirt? It sure was sad and probably the main cause of all my tissues...

reviewText:
Lo' and behold, fans of Ys and Mana series . . . this game is definitely worth a playthrough.

Be warned, the story is an emotional rollercoaster... I am a complete wimp when it comes to well-written somber stories.

A story rich Action-RPG that really stirs the heart. Everything about this game was taken into extreme care and consideration for all players.

It is relatively short, the game takes around 4 hours to fully complete. I guarentee this game is not a waste of time.

The only negatives are:
-- Although this game has controller support, you need to use the keyboard at some parts and there is no setting to rebind keys.
-- The grammar is not 100%, seeing as the game is originally Chinese and translations were not done by a professional, so I won't judge too harshly.

You saw the price? Well?

After playing this game, you will begin to wonder if half the games in your library were worth paying for.


+------------------------+
Fun Facts:

Senia (main character) is named and designed after 'Swordsman Ygnizem / Egnigem Cenia', a monster from Ragnarok Online. Both name and appearance reflects this. [ratemyserver.net]

Magaleta (major NPC) is named and designed after 'High Priestess Magaleta / Margaretha Sorin', a monster from Ragnarok Online. Both name and appearance reflects this. [ratemyserver.net]


Mad props to the sole-developer: Holy Priest

reviewText:
just to be clear, while the game is by no means perfect, sometimes you'll find odd things here and there.
but that being said, don't let the price tag of free fool you. this game could have easily been sold for 5-10 USD easily, and still been well, well worth it.
you will find a story that is compelling, music that is amazing, graphics that range from good to amazing, and a combat system that is so fast it may remind some of the battles in 30 second hero.  it may not be the most challenging game (I only really died once on the last boss) but this means you get to go through the game and see the story even faster. 5.4 hours and I got to see all 3 endings.
because of the combat system, though, I feel it fair to warn you, if you are more into games that really make you think about how to beat something, you will be dissapointed. everything is, for better or worse, streamlined. the most you'll find is the occasional 'get out of this area before x happens' and 'have to kill x before y'

final verdict: this game is easily one of the best free games you will find anywhere. well worth it.

reviewText:
TLDR: It's good, and it's free. No reason not to play it.

This is a very nice and relaxing game, and I was surprised that I enjoyed it as much as I did. With that said, here's my personal list on the pros and cons of this game:

Pros
- Good story
- Simple but effective crafting system
- Encourages exploration through hidden secrets
- Well-designed bosses
- Great art and music
- It's free

Cons
- Overly simplified combat system for normal minions (It still fits very well with bosses though)
- The elite minions do not retaliate if you use skills, which makes killing them more a test of patience than a challenge. They also just stand there. It would be great if they worked like mini-bosses or something
- A little bit of Engrish here and there, but who cares
- Occasional small bugs (barely even worth mentioning, but still)

Overall, I think there's really no reason not to try this game out. You can also see that the developer is very passionate about gaming for making this available for free despite all the work he put into it.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I love this game go play it, now.......go!

Still here well guess I can take a small break from playing to tell you a little more

Eternal Senia is an RPG Maker game but do not hold that against it, a lot of people have become annoyed by all the RPG Maker games appearing on steam lately and that is unfortunate as many of them are very outstanding games and Eternal Senia is one of these games.

I have spent so much time playing this game and I have become so immersed in its story that I can almost tell you about it off the top of my head, nevertheless I will try my best to give you a good idea of what its all about without spoiling anything.

Eternal Senia, a romantic drama story of the struggles one human will go to save the person they care most for. This story may very well draw you in from the start, as it did me I couldnt help but keep going to find out what will happen.

The combat for this game is a fairly standard for those who have played a lot of RPG Maker games and is much easier than most games not saying that thats a bad thing though. The battles can all be  won using strategy rather than sheer force, some grinding may be needed.

For the most part if you keep your wits about you, you will get through with no real trouble. However grinding can be very worth it, there is huge amounts of loot which can be crafted to make the game more enjoyable.

Length wise Eternal Senia is not the longest RPG Maker games I have come across, but it doesn't need to be it tells its story well in the period of time needed, any longer and the feel would be completely off, as if to make it worse by drawing it out so though some will be disappointed at its short length it is for the best.

As for replayability, the game has 3 endings These do not require the game to be replayed from the start, as you can just save before the final boss and change your accessories before the fight each time.

These accessory combinations will provide the various endings of the game. Having said that I replayed the game from the start each time as I found that more rewarding.

Overall Eternal Senia is beautifully written piece of work it has an Interesting Storyline; It is visually appealing, the characters are interesting, a simplistic and fluid combat system, and  3 diferent endings which make those replays worth it.

I'll leave you with this, I have replayed this game so many times, it is perhaps one of the best  RPG Maker games Ive played in a little while and given how much time Ive sunken into it I guess thats sort of evident huh?

Eternal Senia is just that good of a game and will no doubt keep you interested throughout its duration, and its absolutely free, if thats not a good reason to check it out I dont know what is....so why not give it a try.

(Like all my reviews I do not put a score as it is my belief that games like all forms of art are subjective and therefore it is impossible to afix a number to them)

reviewText:
A small solid game
It's great to see various games pop-up, and
when I saw a free RPG maker type game I couldn't resist.

The gameplay is pretty simple, yet there are various little things to
find that makes it more interesting. Also, even though it's an RPG,
there's quite little grinding needed, as boss battles can be beaten
with smarts, not just pure muscle.

The music is enjoyable, and doesn't get annoying, and while some sounds
are stocks from rpg-maker database, it's acceptable for this size of game.

As for the story... well, it's decent, though slightly predictable, I liked it.

Overall, a decent game to spend two-three evenings with. For some it might
be a relaxing ride, for beginners, it might even be a fun challenge. I recommend
it 100 %. (Unless you're one of those who cannot stand RPGmaker games).

reviewText:
Solid, pretty, touching and primarily free.The battle system is not hard, every system is actually really easy to understand. It has really nice menu, nice grephics, nice art, nice music, and of course, nice story.
The story revolves around on Seina, who’s searching for her sister, Magaleta, in the deep Tower of Eternity. The story progresses as Seina became stronger with a companion a forest fairy. The game itself is pretty simple, you grind, boss fight then move to the next stage. It doesn’t matter if you want to finish the game early or late, as long as you didn’t trigger the event, it won’t move to any more stages which is good, because you can actually overpower the bosses and finish the game easily. But that’d be a really long way to play the game.

So, judging from the graphic. The art are good, especially the CGs. It’s so awesome as hell. Did the dev illustrate it by himself? I dunno, it looks awesome, really. Except for the characters sprites, the pixelated one. The monster, forest and especially the last stage are beautifully crafted. The sprites are really good. Monsters too, even some got from packs, I think. The character sprites look off because it felt a bit too tall. But I don’t really care about that. Every interface that this game shows is amazing. A plus point for the last stage too. It’s awesome as hell.

Next, sounds and music. I think the sounds got from some packs. I don't know. Maybe the dev also create some by himself. But it’s actually really good. The sounds are not off from the expectations of things. It’s not weird, not too exaggerating too. The music is fairly simple, the several seconds loop from the main menu is actually fits some of the scenes. There are also some piano solo thingy which is pretty nice. I hope I can download the soundtrack though. I’d pay for that.

Story. I don’t want to feel this again, man. The story is amazing! It has everything you would expect. First, you know nothing. As you defeat the bosses, you know a thing. At the end of the game, you know everything. Even though there’s one character that you never ever see in-game, but in the end, you don’t want to lose that character. I got all the endings and I want to shed my tears. The game is just too beautiful and … I don’t want to spoil anything so play this game. Seriously!
That concludes my feelings for this game. I rate it 9/11 420 666 satan blaze it. Play this game. Would tear up everytime.

reviewText:
If I may say, AVOID the screenshots in the Steam's Store Page, it contains spoilers. Spoilers aren't good, especially for a story driven game like this.

Now for the review....

A simple (A)RPG anime game.

Game's made in RPG Maker, and there's a real work for the story and the gameplay. Note that this game does NOT support Steam Cloud, Achievements and Trading Cards. Be careful with your save games.

As commonly found in RPG, there's a skill system where you allocate points to make the character stronger as you beating the game and level up. You can also craft the equipments with materials found from dead monsters/chests. The battle doesn't take away you from main screen, but instead you'll be fighting enemies in the same screen without transition. Consider this as Devil May Cry in 2D sprites.

There's literally zero effort in progressing, though, as the game even allows you to utilize easy mode during 'hard' boss battles. As it stands, the main appeal of the game is the story and I agree, the story is that good despite of it being a simple theme - the girl who's looking for sister.

There are multiple endings, not difficult to find as the game even hints you how to get them. Make sure you save often on a different save slots.

And I'm surprised this comes with free price tag. So, if you have the slightest interest in Japanese anime-based game, this game's worth trying for.

Looking forward to playing the sequel - developer said it is coming.

PS: The OSTs etc are located in: D:\games\Steam\SteamApps\common\Eternal Senia\Audio (depending on where you install the game). The audio is quite well composed.

8/10 solid game.
voteText: 34 of 42 people (81%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent little action RPG, paced perfectly to fit its length of several hours (with multiple endings).  Intuitive, easy-to-learn, and fast-paced battle system, custom-designed within RPG Maker by the developer.  Extra easy and hard difficulties are available to allow players to experience the story easily and to challenge players, as well as some optional sidequests.  Great selection of music -- drawn from royalty-free sources, I think, but that doesn't make it any less good of a selection, and the music is quite memorable.  Beautiful character art and well-designed environments.

And best of all, a well-written emotionally intense story.

Highly recommended.  There are a few typos, but they don't detract from the quality of the storytelling.  And the game is free anyway.  But it's so good that I'd be willing to pay for it.  It even includes developer commentary that is accessible after finishing the game.

A beautiful game all around.

(Disclosure: I got this game for free on Steam.  You can too.)

reviewText:
Seeing as my interest in RPGs has gone up recently, thanks to the Hyperdimension Neptunia games, as soon as I saw a free ARPG game with an anime artstyle, I was ready to tackle anything this game was willing to throw at me.

And alas, I don't think I was very disappointed.

Now, as always, my reviews are spoiler-free when it comes to reviewing single player games, so don't worry about having the story spoiled. I'm just gonna give my general thoughts.

The Story (no spoilers!)Personally, I think the story could've been paced better.
In my opinion, it moves way too fast with things, introduces new characters and gets rid of them along the line with no idea as to where they've gone.
But as for the story itself? Well, it really is nothing new, but it works surprisingly well. The story is, without a doubt, sad and can invoke a bit of emotion into you.

The CharactersIn terms of characters, well...I can't really comment. Character development does exist in this game, yes, but as for the characters themselves, I don't know, we only have a handful of characters in this game, most of them being rather similar to one another. The characters weren't exactly too interesting to begin with, but again - the development throughout the story is nice, so it gets some points there.

The GameplayEternal Senia has really simple gameplay. WASD to move and a bunch of hotkeys for the specific menus and skills. How do you attack? You basically charge into the enemy and Senia will automatically attack, whilist receiving damage herself. First time users might get confused at the controls at first, but about 15 minutes in, you should get the hang of it. As for Senia's movement, it's decent, but a little bit slippery. Granted, there were a few instances where I accidentally walked into a different room without my intention to, but those moments were few and far inbetween. Throughout the game (and by that, I mean a grand total of 3 times), you will encounter special NPCs"

reviewText:
Alright. Reviewing a free to play game once again.

This is a game created by a game lover. RPG lover to be precise.

It's a very simple Action RPG. The whole game is quite straight forward with minimum amount of puzzle and Mazes.

There are a few secret chest that's a bit hard to find.
But generally it's a very relaxing and non-demanding game.
The game itself is very short, 3-4 hours worth but you can possible play longer if you want to.

Music is basic and okish with no voice acting. (small indie game after all).

The biggest + for this game are two:
1. Wonderfully touching story with multiple ending.
2. Interesting designed boss with 3 different difficulty.

For some challenge and extra intense action i recommend everyone to beat all 3 boss on hard difficulty.
The last one is very hard but just ignore the chaos and act quickly and decisively.

One extra hint/recommendation i have for everyone is go to keyboard setting and disable sticking key for the final boss.
(so you have more percision on control when you move around. You want to click up key to move 1 up. To avoid holding up too long and move up 2 square.).

for Freebie... 9/10.

If it wasn't free to start i would pay 1-2 dollar for this game and rate is 7/10.

reviewText:
A perfect example of how a fast, engaging, entertaining and lovely ARPG should be made
Ratings:

History: 10/10 - Would cry again.
Gameplay: 9/10 - Fast ARPG, easy combat system but still entertaining.
Soundtrack: 9/10 - OST is great and fits every part of the gameplay. Short game so there is no need for more music variety.
Graphics: 9/10 - What did you expect? Almost everything in the whole game was made by a single person in just one year, even scripting. The sprites fits perfectly the characters he wants to show and there's no need for movement in boss battles. Wouldn't you be expecting for him to create sprites for every kind of enemy right?


Information:

Duration: ~4h on a normal run, ~6h on a completionist run. This mixed with the easy combat system allows one to easily start a new run after doing the first one and complete it at 100% in less time than the first run.
Combat System: ARPG, or for anyone that doesn't know what it is, in a vague explication, fighting in the same world as you move.
Crafting system: More easy impossible. Whenever you enter a new dungeon, you will have available new items to craft. Gather 2 materials, create a basic item, gather 2 more items and the previous one you crafted, upgrade that one to a better one. You will have a total of 4 new items to craft of each kind when entering a new dungeon.
Items: A Sword, a Gauntlet, a Cape, an Armor and an Accesory. You can craft every one of them except for the Accesories, which you will need to (easily) find.


Conclusion:

Bruh, you are seeing all these good comments, it's F2P and a very few hours short. Just give it a try, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
This game was a great, calming, pleasurable experience. The gameplay is simple and isnt just about button mashing. The story is well written and you get attached to the main character easily...

The game is really well done, with pretty locations, some puzzles, mob grinding is easy enough and weirdly addictive... The OST is great and has a head-bop rhythm to it at times.

!Potential Spoiler!

You work your way through three dungeons, working to find and save your sister. You work your way through towards the three endings hoping all the while for a happy ending only to be spin-drop-kicked in the balls of your feels... Three endings and none of them are what you hoped for but they are still good, still worth the feels...
For a free to play game this is a great time passer and it has worked its way to one of my favourites..

Now I swear to ♥♥♥♥ if they dont make a sequel to this, where they do a happy ending I will kidnap the Holy Priest (in game reference) and hold him captive, subjecting him to vigorous tickling, until they make a sequel, or he writes and  reads me a detailed happy ending to this

OVA: 10/10 would get spin-drop-kicked to the feels again.

reviewText:
A story about eternality never ends well...
Eternal Senia is a basic Anime RPG that is meant to give a relaxing take on RPG games.

StoryMagaleta, Senia's older sister, goes missing and Senia is determined to find her. Throughout the game, Senia will regain flashbacks and discover her past and what really happened to Magaleta.

GameplayThis is a very basic RPG. I like to think of it as Pokemon, but you instantly attack enemies by simply walking into them (Note that you can also take damage from them). You have a normal attack with your sword and multiple special attacks that consume SP.

Crafting and upgrading your gear is very important, as you may have trouble getting past areas if you don't have the best armor or an upgraded sword. Open the craft menu every once in a while to see if you can craft something better.

You will also encounter stationary bosses. These can be annoying since you attack and wait for your health to come back and you keep repeating this process. Though, its worth it since you will get a huge amount of XP and maybe a cool item.

SoundSoundtrack is quite pleasant. You have music ranging from violin, piano, and some electronic bass. Game sounds are a throwback to the nostalgia days of top down RPG games.

Should you play this game?If you have never played an RPG before, this is a simple game to start. It takes around 305 hours to complete. Three if you just want to get to the ending(s) as fast as possible.

P.S. You might want some tissues if you get feels.

Can't believe this is a free game!

If your into RPG and hack and slash with an oldschool feeling, you should definitely try this!

reviewText:
I was going to write a review once I finish this game but I can't wait any longer. People must know about this!

I don't know if the Ragnarok references in this game were intentional or mere coincidence (which I doubt) but the moment I saw High Priest Magaleta, I knew I'm gonna love this. It was basically the reason why I got addicted.

The game starts off really slow. It comes off as a generic RPG made with VX Ace. The story doesn't begin until the player has gone through the basic controls. Honestly, I was bored to death in the beginning but it didn't take long until the game picked up. There's more to the game than just playing it and I'd like to mention a few. First and foremost would be the nicely written story. It has a lot of emotions in it and it was constructed well to go with the game's mapping design, before you know it, you'd be sucked into the fantasy setting of the game, which is something that modern RPGs lack. The art style is worth complimenting as well as it is amazing. From the menu CG, to the character sprites, to the game objects. The characters have their distinct personalities that amplifies the fun. There's the ever-so-stubborn protagonist, Senia; the composed and caring big sister" figure

reviewText:
Eternal Senia takes you on an epic journey through the eyes of a young girl named Senia. Although simple in presentation, this game exemplifies how the ARPG genre should be through innovative changes to classic mechanics and a strong focus on story and ambiance.

The graphical style and user input are sure to inspire feelings of nostalgia for gamers over 30. A throw back to a time when fundamental game play mattered more than death counters or clicks per second, Eternal Senia is a fresh new experience that anyone looking for a little bit of relaxing fun at any age should be able to pick up and enjoy.

This game has:
immersive atmospheric effects and high quality background music
replayability due to sections of randomly generated content and multiple endings
side quests for collectables and optional boss monstersGame developer and publisher Holy Priest has delivered a gift in the form of Eternal Senia, completely free of charge, back to the game-playing community that embraced him many years ago within Ragnarok Online. I have no doubt that others who take the time to experience this labor of love will be similarly motivated by his inspirational work.

In the end, the game is shorter than I would like. I also would have preferred more graphics options including native support for 16:9 displays and the ability to play in a windowed fullscreen mode, however these are minor technical points compared to the positive aspects of the game. For what is essentially a hobbyist project, Eternal Senia is an unqualified success worth taking note of.

9/10

reviewText:
[TL;DR at the bottom]

Eternal Senia surprised me quite a bit. As a free ARPG made through the RPG Maker, I really did not have high expectations and downloaded it mainly due to the “Overwhelmingly Positive” response by the community.
As such the game sat months in my Steam Library before today I finally thought “Man, would I love to play through a quick Adventure.” – and man did I get that.

To start off, you’re playing as Senia. A slightly 2-Dimensional character, who at first glance doesn’t care about anything other than saving her “sister” Magaleta” who went into the “Tower of Eternity” for reasons unknown at the start of the game. The first ten minutes you’re fighting through a couple of trashmobs and get introduced to the games mechanics. Most notably the combat mechanics, which I’ll talk about in a bit.

Essentially the game is divided in three separate parts outside of the tutorial. Each of them is basically one big dungeon with 2-3 Cutscene’s, which is also the only time in which you’ll find any dialogue, exposition or character development, as there are barely any characters besides Senia and Magaleta, but every one follows the same structure.
What I mean by that is, that you have your dungeon, with your fair share of enemies, which after the first dungeon do not pose any threat whatsoever, if you’re somewhat decently equipped, but each dungeon has an “Arcane” version as well, in which you simply go through around 10 rooms, grinding again for crafting material. Which you’ll do, since the Upgrades are quite important, especially if you’re attempting the Hard-Modes of each of the three bosses.

Each of the 3 dungeons introduces a minor gimmick, which however isn’t really enough to set them apart and thus the gameplay can become quite stale if you’re not used to “grindy” games like other games from the ARPG-Genre.
Also at the end of each dungeon you’ll find 3 NPC’s who award you with special and sometimes important items for essentially 100% completing each segment. It’s a neat little bonus which you’ll most likely be going for anyway if you’re even interested in maxing out your Equipment before shooting for the next dungeon.

The game does have a really simplistic crafting system, which you’ll have to use, since there aren’t any drops from the enemies you defeat. Additionally you only have 1 Set of Armor and Weapons for each dungeon. As such you’ll be playing as a Swordsman and only as a Swordsman, which can get quite boring, adding to the stale combat system and the grind for equipment.

The combat system being quite simple: Through the game you unlock 4 special attacks which use Mana-Points and any other attack is done by simple bumping into enemies – quite like the first YS game. Having completed the game 100% (every challenge) and every Boss on Hard Mode, I did only actively use the first 2 Special Attacks and the 3. as an activator for some of the puzzles and even the second one only for Groups of enemies. As such only a single skill was somewhat important for any of the boss fights.

Speaking of which, the boss-fights are quite challenging, though basically share many attack patterns with one another, which can more or less be blamed on the game being made with RPG-Maker. Nonetheless all were fun to play through and each one had just enough innovation over the last one to keep the fight somewhat new and exciting.
The last thing I do want to talk about, since it somewhat surprised me – is the conclusion of the game. Like I mentioned earlier: the characters are quite 2-Dimensional, not only do we exclusively hear about Senia only caring about Magaleta, but also only learn about a tiny part of her backstory. On the other hand, Magaleta’s only exposition is during the finale of the game. The story very much falls apart by not explaining the concept of the “Eternity” Senia is plagued with throughout the game and we also do not learn about any of the few other characters we do encounter.
So that begs the question, if the story, lacking so much detail is good enough to justify a playthrough, especially if any given person isn’t that much used to ARPG’s?

I’d argue yes. For a number of reasons: The most important being, that the story heavily relies on the conclusion, which is filled to the brim with emotional and somewhat manipulative dialogue and great exposition about the true feelings of both Magaleta and Senia. Each of the endings is smartly designed, the first one basically asking the player the question: “Did you pay attention to the dialogue, we DID present to you?” – which for me was a great feeling to then see this detail playing a role in the finale.
I’ll obviously not spoil any of the endings, but just say that it reminded me a bit of the Key-Visual Novels, especially planetarian in terms of writing style.

In conclusion, I’m not sure if I’d recommend Eternal Senia solely for the ending and I do have to say “for the ending”, since I can’t recommend the story in its entirety. What I can do whoever is recommend Eternal Senia for the great conclusion, the ability to make the player bond with characters he/she barely gets to know over the course of just a couple of hours, I can recommend it for the surprisingly good Soundtrack, throughout the entire game and lastly for making the albeit negative grind a very rewarding experience, once you finally finish any of the dungeons and finally get to face one of the bosses.


TL;DR
+ Fluent difficulty (Easy Mode / Hard Mode)
+ Rewards Completionism
+ Great ending (The entire last dungeon)
+ Good Soundtrack
+ Solid length
+ Great art
+ It’s free


+/- Very grind-heavy

- Not enough character development
- Senia’s exposition can get a bit repetitive
- Lackluster in detail (Eternity / Sidecharacters)
- Overworld “Boss” Monster completely lacking AI - why not make the Gems they drop a reward from the Arcane Dungeons?


Keep in mind that my critique of the story is quite subjective, as one could argue, that the story doesn’t need to flesh out those details to get its point across – and I’d agree with that, although presenting me with those elements and then just “forgetting” about them (e.g. the game completely forgets about Senia’ sidekick during post-finale) did seem a bit silly to me. However none of it is a reason not to give Eternal Senia try.

reviewText:
Eternal Senia, an ARPG with one of the most emotional stories ever, and as such ill leave it to you to witness it with your eyes. The game is very simplistic, following the normal ARPG elements, skill points, experience, crafting items, upgrading your gear, etc.

The story part is what makes the game so good, it will leave you in tears. The music only adds in to the emotional atmosphere, sometimes being peaceful and sometimes being a very nice song combining piano and violin, I am talking about The Other Side of Sorrow, highly recommend listening to it.

There are 3 different endings. All of them being very emotional as expected of this game. I won't spoil anything of them. Just watch them

As a way to end it, try this game as it is free, and it's worth your time. To me this game feels like an emotional wave, constantly keeping you emotions pinned, but still it made me enjoy every single moment of it. Can't wait to see the sequel, if it will come.

reviewText:
for a RPG Maker made Hacky-Slashy Game - its not half bad.
Actually, its good. Its simple to control (you walk up to enemies and touch them to attack them, and the enemy counters), QWER do special skills which you learn bit by bit and thats pretty much it.

With 3 to 4 hrs of playtime and 3 endings there is some good mileage from this game, and since its F2P, even better.
the music for the Dungeons is atmospheric and high Quality, I feel like I know the music from some scenes somewhere, but cant really point my finger on it

as much as I liked the game, there is a few things that nag me a bit

first of all - typos and Grammar. I know the guy who made this is chinese and english isnt his native language, but somethimes it just flings you out ofthe experience
secondly - two of the secrets in the second area are just counterntuitive. One uses the ability of a monster against a certain object, which is done once and only once, and the second one interacts with an object that has come up various times in the game already, but never gave any response.
As third - Due to the way the game operates, Battles are mostly luch based. Unlike in for example Ys you cant outkite the enemies, sneak a hit here and there and never take a hit yourself. But when you get good equip on the current floor, you're normally pretty well off.

And something about balancing - the minute you can breeze through the Sanctum on every floor, you are set for Life, since (especially after the 1st floor) you can exchange one Elite Crystal for 5 of each material and 2 Elite Crystals are guaranteed to drop each run (Mid Boss and End boss) farming for materials is pretty much done there.
Also why the things in the 2nd ending happened is a bit beyond me, but whatever, I guess.

All in all, try the game out. Its good.

PS:Is it just me or does Senias design really borrow a lot from Ragnarok Onlines Swordman(F)?

reviewText:
Eternal Senia is an a RPG Maker game. Before I continue this review, I best get that out of the way, so that those of you who detest the engine and it's games can move on.

Now, having said that it is an RPG Maker game. I must admit, I myself was highly sceptical that this would be any good. But, the screenshots and art style drew me in and so did that ever so kind price tag of: FREE! So, onto the review.

Narrative
First item on the list, the narrative. Eternal Senia is a romantic tale in as many ways as it is a drama. It's a tale of the length and extent one human will go to, to save the person whom they love. It's a tale about the psychological pressure's one will experience metaphorically whilst fighting for the place in the rightful eyes of those whom they hold dear. In essence what I'm trying to say is that, the tale, whilst short and fairly simplistic. Is a good one. It kept me hooked for the duration of the game and it made me intrigued enough to continue pushing on through to find out what happens in the end. Yet the end, is a fascinating feels trip, and (depending on which ending you get) may not satisfy what you wanted all along and make you question the outcome. Something in my personal opinion, any good RPG should be aiming for. To get the player to ponder and question the outcome is a good tale indeed.

Combat
Now, from the storyline to that of the most important aspect, the combat. The combat for this game is a fairly standard affair for those of you who have played non turn-based RPG Maker games and is in fact much easier than most standard games as this was the developers intention. The battles/boss battles can all be fought and won with strategy and tactics rather than sheer force, for those of you who are less interested in grinding. Having said that, the frequency of save points, the arcane realm (an in-game arena of sorts) and the huge amount of loot drops which can be crafted make the game's grinding seamless and in many cases you will not feel it a chore to level up. I myself managed to make to the level cap by the end of the game without realising as the various collectible side-quests" you get in each dungeon quickly increase your exp without noticing. So
recommended: you're in luck as you're partly rewarded with this game. This all goes hand-in-hand with the developers intentions of creating a simple to play story based RPG. It should aslo be noted
hoursPlayed: that the game also makes use of key-binded "skills" gifted to the player throughout the game. These skills are used for a variety of combat situations and occasional puzzles. These skills can also be upgraded using SP (Skill Points) which are awarded to the player after killing enemies in-game. Also
voteText: throughout the game
helpfulPercent:
some enemies will drop pages or even books as a loot. These pages and books can be used to award permanent boosts the player's overall skills. You will also be awarded more of these if you complete the additional "side-quests". That is all that can be said for the combat of the game. Now we move onto:

Length & Replayability
Length/Replayability. This game as you might have guessed is indeed a short one. Given that it is a free game I'm sure you could not have expected it to be particularly long. The game by itself without gathering the collectibles or killing monster kings should take you no more than 3 hours. If you're a perfectionist collecting every item and completing the "side-quests" should yield a time of 4-5 hours. If you were to present yourself a challenge and attempt the game's bosses on hard mode
votesHelpful: you'd find yourself looking at a modest 5-6 hour timespan. As for replayability
votesTotal: the game has 3 ending outcomes. These do not require the game to be replayed and all you need to do is make one save before the final boss (you will be given ample warning of this in-game) and then change your accessories before the fight each time. These accessory combinations will provide the various outcomes for the game. So
votesFunny: there is not much in the way of replayability.\n\nNow for those who skim read
commentsCount:
here's a pro/cons list and a TL;DR:

---Pro's---
- Interesting Storyline.
- Simplistic
column16:
yet fluid combat system.
- Easier combat system for casual players/RPG newcomers.
- Acheivable and short collectible "side-quests"
- Simplistic yet effective character customisation.
- Upgradeble skills.
- 3 Endings.

---Con's---
- Story is slightly cliche in places.
- Short gameplay time.
- Combat can become slightly repetitive.
- Occasional RPG Maker puzzles.

TL;DR: The game is good. it's free

reviewText: This game got me hooked in the first few minutes. Although the core of the game is relatively simple, the elements were very well executed. In terms of the actual gameplay, the battle system is very easy to learn, boss battles are challenging with different modes and crafting is very simple yet effective. The story is solid for a very short game, and goes well with the soundtrack (which is one of the best I've heard for games of this caliber and genre).\n\n9/10. Definitely replayable and would recommend to others.

reviewText:
so, i finally finished this game o-o
well, i am surprised how much content it has for a free game.
the story is amazing but ... well, sad ... peoples with a kind heart and feelings (like being able to go along with the story and feeling with the characters) will have it here and there really hard to keep the tears in their eyes. cold hearted peoples wont have any trouble with it tho ^^

so, about the gameplay~.
the fight system is really simple and easy to handle but since the game has a really good story is there a really nice balance between both of them. what i mean is: the battle system is maybe simple but the story keeps you in the game and you just want to continue and i dont mean it like that it would be a pain to push the story forward because the battle system is a bit simple. it makes fun even tho that it is simple ^^.

so yea here the good aspects of the game.
-for an rpg maker game, well made, here and there a few bugs but only IF you provoke it.
-the fight system is simple but good at the same time.
-amazing story line
-ragnarok online fans will love this game even more then peoples which dont know ragnarok online or knowing it not at all. why? if you get curious why, download the game and play it. you might notice it instant x3!
-many monsters and not simply recolored monsters. for a free game is that definitly a plus
-the boss fights are really well made. again, for a free game is this aswell stunning and a plus too!

now to the negative site, this has 1 spoiler AND ITS A SERIOUS ONE!!!! xD dont frigging hover your mouse over it if you dont want to get spoiled!!!
-the little mini bosses (the big monster versions) which giving you the legendary stones have absolutely 0 AI ... they just standing there ... they wont come after you so~ you could just standing there, regenerating MP and using phantom strike where you get 0 conter damage ^^''
the game has absolutely no happy end. there is NO GOOD ENDING! ofcourse theres a really bad ending but the other 2 endings (if you collect everything ingame and getting all chests) are not satisfying and will kill your eyes aswell. this is for me a big - point and i really hope the dev will give the sequel a happy end

so, i am done with this review. i write rarely reviews tho but, i thought this game deserved one since it is a free game and the dev team putted so much effort into it and still dont want any money for it. i would definitly pay money for the sequel!

reviewText: Free. Simple. Great Artwork. All of these words describe the first impression of this game. Furthermore, the game goes deeper in content with a great soundtrack that coordinates with its good storyline. A 16-bit rpg with D-pad controls and skill button is as simple this game goes for its action mechanics. Also, the game doesn't include any town or currency,but a crafting system and skill point system that allow players to upgrade as they advance on. However, the storyline have many emotional ending that makes you want to replay the game for more hours. HIGLY RECOMMENED FOR OLD 16-BIT GAMERS AND VISUAL NOVELERS!!!!\n\n

reviewText: This game is amazing, but it makes you REALLY think. The combat is amazing, the art style is amazing and the story line is amazing. Upon completing this game, I actually fell asleep, and when I woke up, I felt EXTREMELY lonely, like I lost something precious to me. No game has made me cry like this one. Chrono Trigger had an impact on me, but not of this Magnitude. I honestly wish I could find the right words to how I feel, but no words can describe EXACTLY how I felt after this game, other than, Pain, Lonely and Sadness. This game gives you so many feels, but it is totally wirth the play. I'm probably going to play through it again, but everyone be wary, you will most likely cry with this game.

reviewText:
I know many players aren't even trying to play small 'free to play' game, but this one is really worth it !
In shortcut : As for Free to Play, Eternial Senia is really worth a try and it's gonna make you cry !
Highly recommend this game to all RPG players, that like 'feeling trains'.

If you like to play games made in RPG Maker, then i strongly recommend you to play this one. It has really amazing story, that is making cry few times. The music always fits in situation and it sounds really beautiful. After playing first stage, there are thoughts like 'what's wrong with those fights ?'. Keep playing anyway ! The game changes pretty quickly and fights become really oryginal. What really surprised me, was actually boss fights. I really like them, the bosses aren't moving at all, but they are spawning minions and throwing spells at you so if you want to beat them in hard mode, you must keep trying and changing different strategies.

What are you gonna like :
- Story
- Music
- Arts
- Fight system
- Characters
- Boss fights
- Unique spell casting by monsters
- Skill system
- 'Feeling trains' - the cry is real

Now what's gonna irritate you :
- Facial expression of Fairy is always the same, it's something that really hurts the eyes.
- Crafting system is not complicated, but it's getting booring after gathering same materials but with different names.
- To craft better item, you have to remove it from your active equipment, upgrade it, then equip it again. That's getting annoying !

For once more : Even through some irritating stuff, this game is amazing and is worth a try !

reviewText:
Happened upon this freebie by accident, and despite something of a distaste for RPGMaker projects decided there wasn't any harm in giving it a try...turns out I stuck with it to the end, and chances are if the thing interests you enough to merit a download the same will hold true for the reader.

On a basic level the game feels something like the older Ys titles - you and the enemies move around in real time, and if you bump into them you exchange damage. There's not a heckuva lot of technique to it at first, but as you progress you add a handful of special attacks (a dash slash, a projectile, etc.) to your arsenal, which will come in handy against foes which put up a better fight when approached head-on - since your life and special attack points gradually regenerate the game never gets too difficult (hardly surprising, considering that's one of the creators' stated goals), but for the handful of hours it lasts things stay engaging enough to keep things moving. If you want to find everything you'll likely end up taking a second trip through, as I did, and do so with a closer eye on your surroundings to sniff out persnickety hidden stuff that seems stupidly obvious once you've noticed it.

Visually, Eternal Senia makes pretty good use of both stock assets and original artwork - the three sections (four, if you count the intro) of the tower you have to climb, and the baddies dwelling within, are distinct if somewhat predictable, and the music, while not particularly hum-worthy in my opinion, does its job admirably otherwise. The story tying the whole thing together is pretty boilerplate (your adoptive sis went to the tower and hasn't come back, time to head in and find her yourself), but the small handful of characters present are generally low-key and likable, not to mention that each of the three endings, while perhaps a bit melodramatic, will still likely evoke at least a little bit of right in the feels" from many players.

As far as weaknesses go
date: the translation is a bit rough (albeit never enough to obfuscate things to any major extent)
recommended: leveling up your gear and skills to their peak requires some grinding (though the game is still very much beatable without doing so)
hoursPlayed: the only major threats to your well-being come when you're surrounded and trapped by enemies and their area-of-effect magic spells
voteText: meaning most of your deaths (especially if you attempt to bolster the challenge by turning boss fights up to "hard") will be the result of frustrating "pinball bounces" between attacks
helpfulPercent: and while you can fast-travel around each individual area you're not allowed to return to cleared zones to complete your checklist.\n\nOther than that
votesHelpful: I can't really fault the game for being what it is - a simple
votesTotal: breezy
votesFunny: and overall pleasant (not to mention
commentsCount: once again
column16: free) little action-RPG. It isn't likely to light anyone's world on fire
column17: but it isn't trying to
column18: and shouldn't feel any need to. If you're ever in the mood to wander around for a bit
column19: smack some unfriendly sprites upside the head and get strong enough for the next batch in the process
column20: there's no reason not to spend a little time with this unassuming
column21: but warmly genuine

reviewText:
It's a solid retro RPG with very high production values, from art to music to game mechanics.
Is a diamond in the rough, a nostalgic throwback RPG. I thoroughly enjoy playing this 16-bit adventure and strongly recommend it to any true RPG fan.
Like the 16-bit graphics and anime-styled artwork, the sounds and music of this game help add to that classic RPG feeling. None of these things will leave a big impression on you, but they are good for a game like this. The controls are simple. There is also the option to play in either full-screen or window mode.

The Good:
+ Good graphics and sound for a 16-bit game
+ Low CPU usage - runs smoothly on most all systems
+ Full Controller Support

The Bad:
- With tons of dialogue, an auto-scroll timer would be a welcome addition

True RPG fans will want to add this game to their libraries.

reviewText: I figured the least I could do after finishing this game is write up a review, especially after going through the bonus room!\nEternal Senia takes you back to the time when Aveyond and Cute Knight were the ARPG and 'Girly' games back in the early 2000s. You have NOTHING to lose playing this game as the developer has kindly made it free for everyone on steam! Fighting mechanics are very simple and easy. While sometimes I would mix up keys, the only issue I had was the fact that the final attack you learn can get jammed when you bounce back and if you lose a boss fight it can make it very annoying and obnoxious to try and save yourself if you're caught in fire.\nThe story is A LITTLE lacking, not too much. The game play was about 3 hours for me without some craft grinding but it wasn't a bad story. It didn't really have a strong impact and it's kind of straight forward without much immerson. You go to save your sister and fight through all the crap in the world to try and save her with a few flashbacks thrown in. I didn't feel very drawn into the story, I liked the fighting and art. If anything I would say that that is something that could turn people off, but I didn't dislike it either. If there was anything to improve on in follow up games for the developer, that would be the spot to improve on. Also the fairy character was useless except for the attack...that was kind of boring as I forgot about her until I saw her again in the bonus room. If there are going to be characters, have them serve a purpose. But otherwise, beautiful graphics, you can tell the work of one person was put into this for night and day and well worth it. I will be looking forward to a sequel with hopefully the improvements I listed as I feel like that would make this game a snatch up. This game deserves more love and I feel with better story it could be on the level of Aveyond (the original) or Ib!

reviewText:
This game is really lovely and well made. Would give 9/10

Story:
It starts when a young swordswoman called Senia tries to find her High Priestess Sister Magaleta, which vanished into the Tower of Eternity. Following her, you get to know more about the sad background story and emotional relationship between those two.

Gameplay:
This game is doable included all endings and doing all sidequest in about 4-5 hours. It's short but still a lot of fun and once you are into it, you don't really want to stop playing it. As you can see it's an ARPG, so you are basically only playing one character with some skills equipped. A good thing is that you can grind ingredients and craft your own equipment in the game.

Difficulty:
To be honest killing the small mob is really easy it's like u get 0 damage from the mini monsters, only the boss fights are challenging and only on Hard Mode anyway.

Characters:
Really well done, I like the art design and also the personalities of all characters. (might be that I known them from Ragnarok Online, which was my favourite MMO 7 years along)

Music:
Not many different tracks, however some of them are tearjerkers and very emotional, which totally fits perfectly at specific scenes.

It's not the best game I've played, but a real good one.
I'd definitely redcommend it.

reviewText:
A classic style JRPG with easy to learn controls, a nice and short story, a cute and atmospheric music and a simple crafting system. It's a jewel of a game, a labour of passion and love, something that the so-called AAA industry with their DLCs and preorder bonuses has lost these last few years.

I'm glad I picked this one up, and you should too, if you like the genre.

reviewText:
Arguably one of the better ARPGs on Steam. Reasons:

Story: The story is quite solid. A remarkable journey where the sister ventures into danger to find the only family she has left, her sister and will risk anything no matter how small the chances are, to be with her and to back to the Church together. Throughout the Journey Senia is more and more emotional yet never gives up. Determination at  it's finest. 10/10

Gameplay: Simplistic and yet fun. Maybe not the best combat system but it's still one fun game to play. The Game developer didn't try to win us over with the gameplay regardless. We're in it for the story. Even thuogh so the traps, monsters and obstacles to push are fun and joyable in it's own right.    9/10

Grahpics/Visuals:  I can tell they worked hard on it. The characters look absolutely stunning. They display the correct emotions at the correct time. The visuals also impact how we,the player feel about thie story and we feel more emerged into the story, Feeling Senia's pain.  9/10

Music(OST): Ill be honest here and say this game's OSTs are some of the best OST's I've ever heard. Especially the menu music. QUite addicting
date: it's like a mix of rap and hiphop. Anyway the game developers did a good job designing the music. It fits well into the game and they put it in the right times for a better emotional attachment to both the character and the story. 10/10\n\nOverall Rating for Eternal Senia: 9.5/10. It's without a doubt my top RPG at the moment and I hope they'll make a sequel. This game must be explored by other gamers out there who's not looking for anything super fancy
recommended: but a nice little RPG that can take your heart away."

reviewText:
It's a relaxing, cute and simple rpg game that is worth your time.

The gameplay is simple, and gets dull near the end, where you have best equipment so monsters are no threat to you. Boss battles make gameplay more interesting.

The story is deeply touching, but there's not really much to it. It mostly focuses on Senia finding her sister, flashbacks, some friendly fairy, and killing monsters. There is almost no background information to add to the characters, we simply know that Senia likes her sister very very much and vice versa. You learn a bit from flashbacks though.

The drawings are pretty and cute.

To sum up, this game has a specific charm, even without being amazing, you enjoy it. I couldn't really play much games in one sitting before I got bored of them, but I really enjoyed my 5h journey with Senia.

Maybe because it's made with love, passion and honesty.

Something games nowadays ... and we, lack.


Get it, it's free.

reviewText:
so im back with another review and in the last review that i posted i taught you all how to be a coolkid and how not to put a condom on but take it out of the wrapper and scorn the ones who told me to make that review

or some sh*t

but now not only am i going to give you a review on how to be a coolkid multi-billionaire gentleman extroadinaire (i totally spelled that right btw) but also teach you how to make an exceptionally great pie while doing it, all credits go to my good friend Mr Pie

Land sakes alive! we're cooking with petrol now! or some more sh*t

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
All credit to Mr Pie. Youll find him on my friends list somewhere

reviewText:
Hello and this is my first review on steam.
I wouldn't play this if it weren't free but boy this game is great!
Some games charge you $$$ but isn't worth it. This?  THIS IS WORTH IT!

Pros:
Theres a legendary sheep and a sneaky slime.
Free game, wouldn't regret if it sucks (which it doesn't).
Multple endings  All kinda sad though	.
Battle system is great. Not that boring turn based battle.
Relatable protagonist and charming story.
Did I mention a legendary sheep?
Cons:
No cons. Im not kidding, for a game made on RPG maker? This is good.
Maybe some wrong grammar or language but this game has been translated from chinese, so give it a break.

Seriously, if this isn't for you, uninstall it and be done with. You didn't even pay a single buck so don't rant about wasted time.

SPOILERS for attaining the three endings ***Srsly don't open this if your just looking for reviews***

Ending 1 : Don't equip the fixed cross/pendat (you can fix it by going to Nia's grave).
Ending 2 : Equip the cross/penddant and after beating Eternal Magaleta, choose Push her away"
Ending 3 : Equip the cross/penddant and after beating Eternal Magaleta
date:
choose "Do nothing"


P.S. If the author is reading this can you give/sell us (me) the wallpapers and the theme song. Really loved it and would appreciate it. I'd like to acquire them legaly. If you sell those that would be my donation. :)"

reviewText:
I can't believe this game is free. It's better than most RPG Maker games I've played and the combat system and secrets are actually pretty nicely done.

My only two complaints are:

1. PLEASE fix the translation. I know it wasn't initially made for English audiences, but please translate properly. I know there's no price for this game so I could even help the developers if needed. (If someone sends me the full English script, I can improve the English translation. I wouldn't be able to actually translate from another language.)

2. I wish the Crafting system was able to show what you already have equipped and you were able to upgrade the equipment you're already using. I feel like it wastes a lot of time going to your menu a few times to unequip, upgrade and re-equip the armour etc.

Otherwise, this is a brilliant game and I would pay for this if it was cheap.

reviewText:
So I downloaded this game ironicaly. Free? RPG Maker? It has to be terrible. Right?

Wrong.

It is a little short, and the translation is not really top notch, but the game still manages to be amazing. Maybe it was my low expectations, but I honestly legitamently liked every aspect of the game. Music, gameplay, story, characters, setting. Its just an all around good ARPG that you will be suprised to love.

I know you dont beleive me (I didn't when I read the reviews) but give the game a try, its free, and you will like it.

P.S. I was on the verge of tears at the end. Video games rarely get me imotionaly invested, how the hell did this game do  what so many have failed to.

reviewText:
I am a fan of the Pokemon: Mystery Dungeon games, and Eternal Senia brought back fond memories of Explorers of Sky. The gameplay is similar, where you have a top view kind of thing over your character and go dungeon crawling for upgrades and to progress in the storyline.
Grinding for materials to get better equipment can become a chore after a while and you can't die, though. Not being able to die is kind of a good thing, but it kills the point of having to fight the monsters and such. I don't know how she holds on to a sliver of health through three demon lazers, but ok.
Well done artwork and story, though.

Recommended for dungeon crawlers, Pokemon Mystery Dungeon fans, and people with patience.

reviewText:
I had a lot of fun playing this game.
The spells are really fun to use and there are some puzzle elements in the game where you need to use a certain spell to unlock a secret.
I also really liked the crafting part of the game, to have the opportunity to upgrade/craft your gear makes this game that much better.
Boss fights are intresting because of the stuff you need to dodge/kill while trying to deal damage to the boss itself. If you want to engage into the combat system (the mechanics of the first spell for example is really nice) you actually can choose the difficulty for the bosses to be hardcore so its more challenging. I personally only died once before the final boss (no spoilers 4 u), at the medusa to be specific, because that was the first time I needed to dodge a lot of skills or else its game-over.
There are multipple endings which really nice and each ending has a touching feeling to it (excluding the first ending because its just crappy in my opinion......)                            LIKE IF U CRI EVERI TIM, SPODER MUN APPRUVS!!!!!!!! XDDDD
And last but not least..... the music...... Its so fantastic and touching and makes the playing experience so much better and fun, it also has a really big impact on cutscenes by the way.... Sometimes i feel like the game just waits until you go to the next dialogue to unleash the part of the music which is emotional as f***. GAME WHY U DO DIS!

Jokes aside, I would recommend this to anyone who likes ARPG and an intresting plot because damn... this game has some intresting plot twists! There also should be a second season or something because I finished this game (with all the endings, WITHOUT looking on the internet) after about four and a half hours.

Sorry for my bad spelling if you find any... still learning english. :)

reviewText: I give this game a 9.9/10. This game brought me back to a time when I enjoyed the more simple mechanics of RPG's. It had a decent storyline even the it felt a tad rushed. By far this game deserves most peoples respect and I give alot of respect to the developers of this game. The one small issue I had that really made it feel less professional was when upgrading gear a set of gear had the wrong requirements. It asked for the elite fairy stone but it was for a different set of armor. This however didn't take anything away from the joy of the game. For that reason I think that this game should be played by all fans of the RPG genre.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
VERY good game, especially for a free game, and downright amazing for the creator's first game.

Fairly easy combat system, graphics are pretty, music is very nice... I especially like the use of the piano music. Story is engaging. You enter a tower to look for your sister, beating up monsters along the way... and I actually can't tell you much more without giving spoilers. There are 3 endings, all of which are easy to get.

Beating the game is not difficult, finding all the stuff in it can be.

Now the bad. The game is only about 5-6 hours long, but it is free so that is not really an issue, although you're probably going to want more. It is fairly obvious at points that English is the not creator's first language, a few lines here and there that don't read properly, very obvious spelling errors, and if you interact with a certain item in the Sanctum your character's name will show up in Chinese characters instead of English.

It is an excellent way to kill 5-6 hours, and if you like an engaging story this is definitely one to pick up. And hell, it is free game with no microtransactions, give it a go and if you don't like it you can always delete it.

reviewText:
This game is just amazing. It's one of those rare treasures that come along in life that you need to experience at some stage because it's a work of art in itself.

You play as Senia, the titular character, on her quest to find her older sister who allegedly entered the Tower of Eternity, which is said to have the power to grant ones greatest wish. As Senia, you explore the various floors of the Tower, all the while upgrading your skills and weapons with the items you receive for defeating monsters and completing quests.

Pros:
+Amazing story and lore
+Beautiful music
+Cute graphics and character portraits
+Interesting characters
+Fun combat and upgrading system
+Unusual endings

Cons:
-Short story
-Made me waste all my money on tissues because of feels
-Requires a LOT of grinding

All in all, I would recommend this game to anyone who likes rpgs, heartbreaking stories or pretty music :)
9/10

reviewText:
Arguably one of the better ARPGs on Steam. Reasons:

Story: The story is quite solid. A remarkable journey where the sister ventures into danger to find the only family she has left, her sister and will risk anything no matter how small the chances are, to be with her and to back to the Church together. Throughout the Journey Senia is more and more emotional yet never gives up. Determination at  it's finest. 10/10

Gameplay: Simplistic and yet fun. Maybe not the best combat system but it's still one fun game to play. The Game developer didn't try to win us over with the gameplay regardless. We're in it for the story. Even thuogh so the traps, monsters and obstacles to push are fun and joyable in it's own right.    9/10

Grahpics/Visuals:  I can tell they worked hard on it. The characters look absolutely stunning. They display the correct emotions at the correct time. The visuals also impact how we,the player feel about thie story and we feel more emerged into the story, Feeling Senia's pain.  9/10

Music(OST): Ill be honest here and say this game's OSTs are some of the best OST's I've ever heard. Especially the menu music. QUite addicting
date: it's like a mix of rap and hiphop. Anyway the game developers did a good job designing the music. It fits well into the game and they put it in the right times for a better emotional attachment to both the character and the story. 10/10\n\nOverall Rating for Eternal Senia: 9.5/10. It's without a doubt my top RPG at the moment and I hope they'll make a sequel. This game must be explored by other gamers out there who's not looking for anything super fancy
recommended: but a nice little RPG that can take your heart away."

reviewText:
It's a relaxing, cute and simple rpg game that is worth your time.

The gameplay is simple, and gets dull near the end, where you have best equipment so monsters are no threat to you. Boss battles make gameplay more interesting.

The story is deeply touching, but there's not really much to it. It mostly focuses on Senia finding her sister, flashbacks, some friendly fairy, and killing monsters. There is almost no background information to add to the characters, we simply know that Senia likes her sister very very much and vice versa. You learn a bit from flashbacks though.

The drawings are pretty and cute.

To sum up, this game has a specific charm, even without being amazing, you enjoy it. I couldn't really play much games in one sitting before I got bored of them, but I really enjoyed my 5h journey with Senia.

Maybe because it's made with love, passion and honesty.

Something games nowadays ... and we, lack.


Get it, it's free.

reviewText:
What's that you say? A free game you say? A free game with a good amount of content in it? A GOOD free game? Sign me up!

First of all, the story. It's good. Not great, but good. Definetly had me engaged, desperate to see the final outcome. It took me a while to get all three endings but the good news is you don't have to play through the entire game again just to see a different ending. Characters are an important part of any good story and Eternal Senia has some ok characters. You get a decent idea of Senia and Magaleta's personalitys and their backstories which really helped add extra emotional impact to the endings (There are three endings and all of them are real tear jerkers). That being said, they didn't feel quiet as fleshed out as they could have been.
Gameplay in Eternal Senia is really good. Combat is quiet a bit different from the usual RPG affair with no turn based combat or anything like that. Instead you simply run into enemies to attack them and use Q, W, E and R to use special attacks. It's a simple system that works very well with the game. The graphics are also nice and I really liked the artstyle. The music was also really great. Not much else to really say there. Um. Yeah. So it's pretty great. And free. Not flawless though, it's a tad repetitive right at the end and the final boss fight was a bit unfair, it's still a good game.

+Reasonable characters
+Decent story
+Very nice visuals
+Great music
+Simple yet good gameplay

-Characters could have been a little more fleshed out
-A tiny bit repetitive towards the end
-Could have done with at least one happy ending

70/100 - Just a lil' bit 2 sad"


Sequel please? Pleeeeeeeeeeeeeeeaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaase? Pls?"

reviewerDisplayName: Guns don't kill people, LAGS do
reviewText:
I'll be rating this game by a professional standpoint without looking at the price tag, cause this game really deserves a price tag, and yet, the developer decided to give it out for free.

The gameplay is plain and simple, no complex mechanics for gamers who prefer competency in gaming. (like me) As well as a lack of sci-fi flashy art that modern games do, which makes it preferrably to be look from an Indie Game perspective. However, this game does have settling mechanics though, where you can naturally emerge yourself into a fantasy world. The story can be more elaborated still... That's the brief summary.

As this is the first ARPG game I play other than Zenonia, the skills are relatively balanced. Cool thing about the skillsets is that the developer manage to pulled it off, mostly By The Developer Himself, for the game to be balanced. The game isn't long and this saves the time needed to reduce the potential flaws occuring within the gameplay and the story, although, creating a game mostly by working by himself also takes a huge amount of time. As everything seemed fair and 6.5/10 to me, the only thing that enjoyed about this game is that it's immersive.

TBH, I don't like bad/sad endings, nor do I like replaying a game. But there is a sequel for the game. Hooray! For a gamer like me who just love to immersive himself, the only thing that keep me finishing the game is the results.

I play the game, I went through and collected all the seemingly hidden treasure, wanted to further the plot, and I was immersed into completing the game, until the story ends. As there is no neutral button, I can only select Yes and No with ratio of 60%:40% towards whether I should recommend this game or not.


TL:DR the game isn't for gaming freaks who place expectations on a game, yet it's still fun cause it's immersive, where you can complete the game casually.


Story - 6.8/10. Beginning of the story is typical, but the lore is interesting. I'm curious to know the plot, this keeps me going. However, if the lore is deeper, the game could get closer on becoming a masterpiece.

Plot development - 4.2/10. Room for improvement, the plot goes too fast. I want more of the progression of the story. :p

Gameplay - 7.4/10. Really nice and alternative setting in an RPG game where no potions were added. Even as the combat system is repetitive, don't change it, as this is the core of the system's originality. Could do with more stages though.

Art - 7.3/10. Serious yet Kawaii, fitting the theme of JRPGs.

Atmosphere - 8.3/10. Atmosphere = Immersiveness. The music, the story, the graphics, the gameplay, the controls... Everything just fits within the idea of the game.


Is it recommended? Only if you're onto Indie Games.

reviewText: This game isn't going to rival epic 40 hour RPG adventures you might be used to, but I feel that the experience is still worth it for those with an interest in the genre. The game does suffer some technical issues with a lack of easily accessible options where even the resolution is a magnify option that resets everytime you turn the game off. I'm able to look past this to play a game which is a pretty nice little adventure. The challenge isn't as great as it could be since many enemies can't attack unless you attack them, but others will use things like area of effect spells and the majority of bosses throw out more elaborate attack patterns. Exploration offers some optional objectives and a few extras that require a little more thought than progressing forward. With a cost of zero to play it's worth a try.\n\nYou can read a full review of this game here.[www.neoseeker.com]

reviewText:
A simple yet deep game that'll keep you hooked until the end.
The plot is well written and the gameplay is nice, the game is enjoyably challenging even in Hard Mode, and even if the difficulty actually ramps up (a lot) in the final fight, there's a checkpoint right before it so even if you lose (and you are going to, trust me) you can press Z two or three times and be right back into the fight.
Oh, did I say that this little shining star is free to play? What are you waiting for?

P.S: I actually smiled a bit, when I saw the Game Over screen for the first time. I'm terrible.

reviewText:
I love this game. I honestly would pay to play, there are many games that there are paid, and they do not come close to it in quality. The story is very good. Or rather, the way it is developed. The story might be a bit cliché, the sister going to save the other, but the way it is developed is what changes everything.
I loved the music and the effects of the game. I really enjoyed the graphics too. The design of the phases evolves so much! Do not be fooled by the simple design of the first, the forest.
For those who are complaining about the gameplay, the author makes it clear that he wanted something simple so that anyone, even if they are bad at video games, could play. I quite liked, just for simplicity. And the battles that needed to be complex, the boss battles, are really hard. I'm sure none of these people who criticized battles faced the last boss on Hard mode.
Really, normal battles are simple, and the mini boss, standing by scenario, do not use magic or anything, which is kind of illogical, because they are the giant version of monsters that use skills, but they just stand still and reflect damage. You just need spamming spells and wait for your HP and MP to fill until you kill then.
But apart from that I have no complaints, the game even rewards you for exploring and kill monsters (it has three NPCs that give you awards for discovering chests, kill certain monsters and getting upgrades in your equipment). You even has a mode called Arcane Realm that is made to level up and drop craft items.

reviewText:
I can't believe this game is free. It's better than most RPG Maker games I've played and the combat system and secrets are actually pretty nicely done.

My only two complaints are:

1. PLEASE fix the translation. I know it wasn't initially made for English audiences, but please translate properly. I know there's no price for this game so I could even help the developers if needed. (If someone sends me the full English script, I can improve the English translation. I wouldn't be able to actually translate from another language.)

2. I wish the Crafting system was able to show what you already have equipped and you were able to upgrade the equipment you're already using. I feel like it wastes a lot of time going to your menu a few times to unequip, upgrade and re-equip the armour etc.

Otherwise, this is a brilliant game and I would pay for this if it was cheap.

reviewText:
At first sight, the game kinda looked like garbage. I mean, the UI wasn't very attractive, the screenshots didn't spark any interest and the 'special' battle system just seemed boring as hell. But I was confused by the fact that this game was rated overwhelmingly positive". So I gave it a try.

The game ended up being pretty good.

The story is ok. It seems a lot of people went on a feel trip although I didn't
date: bearing in mind that I'm not easily moved by a story.\nThe developer wanted to keep it simple and succeeded: it wasn't too boring after all; I enjoyed my time eventhough things were very linear and upgrading and leveling didn't offer too much. It has interesting puzzles and a few secrets. There is some grinding although I didn't really mind
recommended: because it wasn't too much. But some might think differently about this.\n\nIf you can bite through the bad grammar and don't hate RPG Maker games
hoursPlayed: this game can be very well worth your time
